caseTitle: GHANA COMMERCIAL BANK LTD. HIGH STREET, ACCRA v. THE COMMIS
summary: The Supreme Court of Ghana upheld the enforcement of a CHRAJ decision that found the Ghana Commercial Bank's termination of a manager's employment to be discriminatory and a violation of fundamental human rights under Article 17 of the 1992 Constitution. The manager was dismissed for granting a loan without authorization, while others who approved larger unauthorized loans faced no consequences. The Court held that such disparate treatment constituted discrimination, violating the constitutional right to equality. It affirmed that CHRAJ has jurisdiction over such complaints in private enterprises when fundamental rights are at issue, and that constitutional principles override common law contract doctrines. The Bank's appeal, which challenged the legality and enforceability of CHRAJ's decision, was dismissed.
verdict: Appeal dismissed; enforcement of CHRAJ's decision upheld.
winningSide: Commissioner for Human Rights and Administrative Justice (CHRAJ)
citations: Bannerman-Menson v. Ghana Employers Association [1996-97] SGLR 417
Bank of Ghana v. Nyarko 1973 2 GLR 275, CA
Aryee v. State Construction Corporation 1984 1 GLR 424, CA
Tsatsu Tsikata v. The Attorney General
rationaleHighlights: CHRAJ has constitutional authority under Article 216 and 218 to investigate human rights violations, including in private enterprises.
Termination of employment was discriminatory under Article 17 due to inconsistent application of bank rules.
Statutory human rights principles prevail over common law contract principles in constitutional matters.
Failure to explain differential treatment supports inference of discrimination.
CHRAJ's enforcement of its decision is valid when grounded in constitutional human rights violations.
